prior_works.title: Sparse MRI: The application of compressed sensing for rapid MR imaging
prior_works.authors: Michael Lustig, David Donoho, John M. Pauly
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the compressibility/sparsity prior and objective design that CUPID adapts into an unsupervised, image-domain regularization when only routine clinical images (not raw k-space) are available.

prior_works.title: SENSE: Sensitivity encoding for fast MRI
prior_works.authors: Klaas P. Pruessmann, Markus Weiger, Markus B. Scheidegger, Peter Boesiger
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the parallel-imaging forward model relating coil sensitivities to image formation, enabling CUPID’s parallel imaging fidelity term that proxies data-consistency without requiring access to raw k-space.

prior_works.title: GRAPPA: Generalized Autocalibrating Partially Parallel Acquisitions
prior_works.authors: Mark A. Griswold, Peter M. Jakob, Robin M. Heidemann, Mathias Nittka, Volker Jellus, Jianmin Wang, Berthold Kiefer, Axel Haase
prior_works.relationship_sentence: As the de facto clinical PI method on scanners, GRAPPA’s vendor recon outputs provide the accessible, routine-image surrogate CUPID leverages to instantiate its parallel-imaging fidelity when raw data are unavailable.

prior_works.title: MoDL: Model-Based Deep Learning Architecture for Inverse Problems
prior_works.authors: Hemant K. Aggarwal, Merry P. Mani, Mathews Jacob
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided the unrolled PD-DL template with an explicit data-consistency operator; CUPID retains this structure but replaces k-space DC with a PI-based fidelity computable from clinical recon images.

prior_works.title: Learning a Variational Network for Reconstruction of Accelerated MRI Data
prior_works.authors: Kersten Hammernik, Thomas Klatzer, Erich Kobler, Matthew P. Recht, Daniel K. Sodickson, Thomas Pock, Florian Knoll
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated learning image priors within an unrolled variational formulation; CUPID follows this paradigm but crafts a compressibility-inspired unsupervised prior paired with a novel PI-fidelity term.

prior_works.title: Self-supervised learning of physics-guided reconstruction neural networks without fully sampled reference data
prior_works.authors: Burhaneddin Yaman, Saip A. Hosseini, Steen Moeller, Jutta Ellermann, Kamil Ugurbil, Mehmet Akcakaya
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed PD-DL can be trained without ground-truth images by splitting acquired k-space; CUPID extends this self-supervised principle to settings with no raw data by using parallel-imaging fidelity from routine images.

prior_works.title: Plug-and-Play Priors for Model Based Reconstruction
prior_works.authors: S. Venkatakrishnan, Charles A. Bouman, Brendt Wohlberg
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Inspired CUPID’s decoupling of learned image priors from physics-based fidelity, legitimizing training priors purely on image-domain data while enforcing measurement physics through a separate fidelity mechanism.

synthesis_narrative:
CUPID’s core insight—training physics-driven deep MRI reconstructions without any access to raw k-space—sits at the intersection of compressibility priors, parallel-imaging physics, and unrolled deep reconstruction. Lustig–Donoho–Pauly’s compressed sensing MRI established compressibility as a powerful prior and a workable objective, a principle CUPID repurposes as an unsupervised image-domain regularization when only routine reconstructions are available. The fidelity side is grounded in parallel imaging: SENSE formalized the multi-coil forward model, while GRAPPA became the ubiquitous clinical PI recon on scanners. CUPID leverages this reality by defining a “parallel-imaging fidelity” that can be instantiated from readily available vendor recon outputs, eliminating the need for raw k-space during training.
Model-wise, CUPID inherits the unrolled PD-DL paradigm from MoDL and variational networks—alternating learned priors with physics consistency—yet replaces the conventional k-space data-consistency with its PI-based fidelity. From the learning perspective, SSDU demonstrated that PD-DL can be trained without fully sampled ground truth by exploiting measurement splits; CUPID advances this line by removing the raw-data dependency altogether, expanding applicability to under-resourced sites where only final images can be exported. Finally, Plug-and-Play priors provide the algorithmic justification for decoupling learned image priors from the measurement model, supporting CUPID’s strategy of training priors on image-only corpora and enforcing physics via a separate fidelity mechanism. Together, these works directly scaffold CUPID’s compressibility-inspired objective and its practical, raw-free fidelity formulation.
